Award.AwardTitle: Applications of operator algebra theory to certain problems in analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Junge

The aim of this proposal is to apply methods from the operator of algebras to problems in noncommutative analysis. This includes developing a theory of singular integrals and Fourier multipliers for noncommutative function spaces. The new insights gained from this work should also reflect back on the noncommutative spaces and their differential geometric properties. Another field of applications of tools from the theory of operator spaces lies in quantum information theory. Here violation of Bell inequalities and quantum error correction seems to relate well to the theory of cb-maps from operator space theory.

In real life the order in which certain operations are executed can make a big difference. For example first boiling water and the adding oil is very different from first boiling oil and then adding water. The mathematical community has now fully accepted that one should allow the main object of interest to be performed in a certain order. Noncommutative analysis is about functions and their properties in the realm of non-commuting variables. The most important example here are matrix-valued functions. The theory of classical analysis, such as Fourier analysis or harmonic analysis has a lot to say about functions, and as this proposal intends to show, also about matrix-valued functions. Another natural application of this circle of ideas (the mathematical theory called functional analysis) lies in quantum information theory and the theoretical analysis of channels. Channels are the operation performed signals used to transport data in quantum information theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the lifespan of this grant two major research themes of the PI have been accomplished.

One of the theme provides technical, mathematical tools regarding the analysis of noncommutative spaces. Following the lead from physics, mathematicians consider objects where it matters in which order we perform operations. From daily life experience it is plain obvious that first boiling oil and than adding water leads to a different result than first boiling water and than adding oil. Every operation learned in high school mathematics can be examined, and reinvented allowing order to mater. The mathematical field of noncommutative geometry can serve as an prototype on how such a `quantization' is done for geometry. Here `quantization' is to be understood as technical synonym for noncommuting, although it has a different historical root coming from quantized energy jumps. Developing calculus for noncommutative spaces requires to reanalyze and reinvent classical results from mathematical analysis. The results in this project are based on noncommutative/quantum probability and the theory of operator algebra. The theory of operator algebras was originally  invented to put quantum mechanics on solid mathematica footing. Different tools from the ergodic theory and harmonic analysis all play together in this theory, and all of them had to be adjusted to the noncommutative world to accomplish this first task. 

The second research theme provides mathematical results on so called violation of Bell inequalities. Bell inequalities are famous because they started a solid philosophical discussion on foundations of physics, and are at the heart of all rumors on `teleportation'. From a mathematical perspective Bell inequalities correspond to equations for (hyper) planes separating the outcome of a quantum mechanical experiment from the possible outcome of classical experiments.  Using random techniques on can easily find such equations. The P.I. and his collbarotors entered a slighty competitve race with researchers from computer science in producing large violations in different scenarios.

Closely  realted to these Bell inequalities is a problem formulated by a famous russian mathematician Tsirelson. The result of this funding period support the evidence that this problem is the same as another outstanding famous problem in operator algebras. The P.I. and his coauthers proved one implication, and the full equivalence has recently  established by Ozawa.   

According to the title of this grant, applications of theoretical, operator algebraic tools is a specific objective of the performed work. This has been achived by making concrete connection to other mathematical field (harmonic analysis), and even beyond that making contact with researchers in computer  science and physics.  

On an institutional level this grant supports travel for the P.I., his students, and visitors. These funds make a huge impact on the quality and dissemination of the work. In addition, without the face to face interactions, interdisciplinary can not be initiated. The research environment  created by these funds is of fundamental importance for graduate students. A good mentoring, advising infrastructure is also improtant in atrracting minorities to research groups. 

This particular grant also supported a one year postdoctoral position. This year was very productive and initiated a long term collaboration between the postdoctoral research and the P.I. and ultimatively lead to the competitive results on Bell inequalities.
